issue.title: fix #2293: Properly encode Decimals without any decimal places.

labels.name: awaiting author revision
labels.description: awaiting changes from the PR author

repository.name: pydantic
repository.description: Data validation using Python type hints

issue.body:
<!-- Thank you for your contribution! -->
<!-- Unless your change is trivial, please create an issue to discuss the change before creating a PR -->
<!-- See https://pydantic-docs.helpmanual.io/contributing/ for help on Contributing -->

## Change Summary
Adds a custom encoder for Decimals which handles both decimals with decimal places as well as those without.
<!-- Please give a short summary of the changes. -->

## Related issue number
Closes: #2293 
<!-- Are there any issues opened that will be resolved by merging this change? -->

## Checklist

* [x] Unit tests for the changes exist
* [x] Tests pass on CI and coverage remains at 100% 
  __Tests where at 99% when i ran them before my change, I do have tests covering my changes__
* [x] Documentation reflects the changes where applicable
* [x] `changes/<pull request or issue id>-<github username>.md` file added describing change
  (see [changes/README.md](https://github.com/samuelcolvin/pydantic/blob/master/changes/README.md) for details)

issue.title: jsonable_encoder can't roundtrip properly with ConstrainedDecimal

repository.name: fastapi
repository.description: FastAPI framework, high performance, easy to learn, fast to code, ready for production

issue.body:
### First check

* [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
* [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar issue and didn't find it.
* [x] I searched the FastAPI documentation, with the integrated search.
* [x] I already searched in Google "How to X in FastAPI" and didn't find any information.
* [x] I already read and followed all the tutorial in the docs and didn't find an answer.
* [x] I already checked if it is not related to FastAPI but to [Pydantic](https://github.com/samuelcolvin/pydantic).
* [x] I already checked if it is not related to FastAPI but to [Swagger UI](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-ui).
* [x] I already checked if it is not related to FastAPI but to [ReDoc](https://github.com/Redocly/redoc).
* [x] After submitting this, I commit to one of:
    * Read open issues with questions until I find 2 issues where I can help someone and add a comment to help there.
    * I already hit the "watch" button in this repository to receive notifications and I commit to help at least 2 people that ask questions in the future.
    * Implement a Pull Request for a confirmed bug.

<!-- 

I'm asking all this because answering questions and solving problems in GitHub issues consumes a lot of time. I end up not being able to add new features, fix bugs, review Pull Requests, etc. as fast as I wish because I have to spend too much time handling issues.

All that, on top of all the incredible help provided by a bunch of community members that give a lot of their time to come here and help others.

That's a lot of work they are doing, but if more FastAPI users came to help others like them just a little bit more, it would be much less effort for them (and you and me ðŸ˜…).

-->

### Example

Here's a self-contained, [minimal, reproducible, example](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example) with my use case:

<!-- Replace the code below with your own self-contained, minimal, reproducible, example, if I (or someone) can copy it, run it, and see it right away, there's a much higher chance I (or someone) will be able to help you -->

I wrote the following test/script to showcase the problem, I have a ConstrainedDecimal which represents a `Numeric(22,0)`.

**test_decimal_bug.py:**
```python
from pydantic import ConstrainedDecimal, BaseModel
from decimal import Decimal
from fastapi.encoders import jsonable_encoder


class Id(ConstrainedDecimal):
    max_digits = 22
    decimal_places = 0
    ge = 0


ObjId = Id


class Obj(BaseModel):
    id: ObjId
    name: str


def test_con_decimal_encode() -> None:
    test_obj = Obj(id=1, name="Test Obj")
    cycled_obj = Obj.parse_obj(jsonable_encoder(test_obj))
    assert test_obj == cycled_obj


def test_con_decimal_encode_custom_encoder() -> None:
    test_obj = Obj(id=1, name="Test Obj")
    cycled_obj = Obj.parse_obj(jsonable_encoder(test_obj, custom_encoder={Id: int}))
    assert test_obj == cycled_obj


def test_con_decimal_encode_custom_encoder_2() -> None:
    test_obj = Obj(id=1, name="Test Obj")
    cycled_obj = Obj.parse_obj(jsonable_encoder(test_obj, custom_encoder={ObjId: int}))
    assert test_obj == cycled_obj


if __name__ == "__main__":
    from pprint import pprint

    print_obj = Obj(id=1, name="Test Obj")
    jsonable_obj = jsonable_encoder(print_obj, custom_encoder={Id: int})
    pprint(jsonable_obj)
```

Result from running it as a script
```sh
$ python test_decimal_bug.py
{'id': 1.0, 'name': 'Test Obj'}

```

And with pytest -v
```sh
$ pytest -v test_decimal_bug.py
========================================================== test session starts ===========================================================
platform darwin -- Python 3.9.0, pytest-6.2.2, py-1.10.0, pluggy-0.13.1 -- /Users/hultner/Library/Caches/pypoetry/virtualenvs/hantera-backend-5YPPF0bI-py3.9/bin/python
cachedir: .pytest_cache
hypothesis profile 'default' -> database=DirectoryBasedExampleDatabase('/Users/hultner/dev/hantera/hantera_backend/.hypothesis/examples')
rootdir: /Users/hultner/dev/hantera/hantera_backend, configfile: pyproject.toml
plugins: cov-2.11.1, subtests-0.4.0, testmon-1.0.3, xdist-2.2.0, forked-1.3.0, schemathesis-2.8.5, hypothesis-5.49.0
collected 3 items

test_decimal_bug.py::test_con_decimal_encode FAILED                                                                                [ 33%]
test_decimal_bug.py::test_con_decimal_encode_custom_encoder FAILED                                                                 [ 66%]
test_decimal_bug.py::test_con_decimal_encode_custom_encoder_2 FAILED                                                               [100%]

================================================================ FAILURES ================================================================
________________________________________________________ test_con_decimal_encode _________________________________________________________

    def test_con_decimal_encode() -> None:
        test_obj = Obj(id=1, name="Test Obj")
>       cycled_obj = Obj.parse_obj(jsonable_encoder(test_obj))

test_decimal_bug.py:22:
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
pydantic/main.py:520: in pydantic.main.BaseModel.parse_obj
    ???
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

>   ???
E   pydantic.error_wrappers.ValidationError: 1 validation error for Obj
E   id
E     ensure that there are no more than 0 decimal places (type=value_error.decimal.max_places; decimal_places=0)

pydantic/main.py:362: ValidationError
_________________________________________________ test_con_decimal_encode_custom_encoder _________________________________________________

    def test_con_decimal_encode_custom_encoder() -> None:
        test_obj = Obj(id=1, name="Test Obj")
>       cycled_obj = Obj.parse_obj(jsonable_encoder(test_obj, custom_encoder={Id: int}))

test_decimal_bug.py:28:
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
pydantic/main.py:520: in pydantic.main.BaseModel.parse_obj
    ???
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

>   ???
E   pydantic.error_wrappers.ValidationError: 1 validation error for Obj
E   id
E     ensure that there are no more than 0 decimal places (type=value_error.decimal.max_places; decimal_places=0)

pydantic/main.py:362: ValidationError
________________________________________________ test_con_decimal_encode_custom_encoder_2 ________________________________________________

    def test_con_decimal_encode_custom_encoder_2() -> None:
        test_obj = Obj(id=1, name="Test Obj")
>       cycled_obj = Obj.parse_obj(jsonable_encoder(test_obj, custom_encoder={ObjId: int}))

test_decimal_bug.py:34:
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
pydantic/main.py:520: in pydantic.main.BaseModel.parse_obj
    ???
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

>   ???
E   pydantic.error_wrappers.ValidationError: 1 validation error for Obj
E   id
E     ensure that there are no more than 0 decimal places (type=value_error.decimal.max_places; decimal_places=0)

pydantic/main.py:362: ValidationError
======================================================== short test summary info =========================================================
FAILED test_decimal_bug.py::test_con_decimal_encode - pydantic.error_wrappers.ValidationError: 1 validation error for Obj
FAILED test_decimal_bug.py::test_con_decimal_encode_custom_encoder - pydantic.error_wrappers.ValidationError: 1 validation error for Obj
FAILED test_decimal_bug.py::test_con_decimal_encode_custom_encoder_2 - pydantic.error_wrappers.ValidationError: 1 validation error for Obj
=========================================================== 3 failed in 0.22s ============================================================

```

### Description

<!-- Replace the content below with your own problem, question, or error -->

* Run the test script with `python test_decimal_bug.py`
* It returns a JSON with `{'id': 1.0, 'name': 'Test Obj'}`.
* But I expected it to return `{'id': 1, 'name': 'Test Obj'}`.

### Environment

* OS: [e.g. Linux / Windows / macOS]: macOS & Linux
* FastAPI Version [e.g. 0.3.0]: 0.62.0
* Python version: 3.9.0


### Additional context
When I return the pydantic objects through an endpoint, the IDs show up correctly without the trailing invalid decimal, which further confuses me as the documentation states that this would use the very same encoder.

As you can see in the tests I also tried to register a custom encoder for Ids (both the base class and alias) but this doesn't help.
<!-- Add any other context or screenshots about the question here. -->

body:
@samuelcolvin It's great that the fix for the bug in particular got merged, but thinking further about it. 

Isn't it a bit strange that I still can't provide a custom encoder for the Id type? It would make sense if the encoder I provided would be used. I suspect this is because the actual type checked when encoding is that of the instance and not the type defined in the objects model class. Wouldn't it make sense to check the annotated type first for a custom encoder? 
And if not I think it would make sense to have this limitation clearly documented. 
Of course either way this would then be a new separate (though related) issue as we've already resolved the particular problem with decimals.

issue.title: fix #2293: Properly encode Decimals without any decimal places. (#2294)

* fix #2293: Properly encode Decimals without any decimal places.

* doc: Added changelog entry.

* refactor: Move ConstrainedDecimal test from separate file into test_json

* docs: Remove prefix from changelog.

* test: Changed test_con_decimal_encode to @samuelcolvins recommendations
